name: Identical Vowel Merging
mechanism: When the same vowel appears at the end of one word and the beginning of another, they merge into the long form. This is phonological merging at the boundary.

examples.annotation: raama + aaditya → raamaaditya (a + a → ā)
sarva + ada → sarvaada (a + a → ā)

name: Long Vowel Merging
mechanism: When a long vowel appears before its short counterpart, the long form dominates. This follows the principle of syllable weight - heavy before light.

examples.annotation: maha + arjuna → mahaarjuna (ā + a → ā)

name: Guna Formation
signature: a + i → e, a + u → o
mechanism: When 'a' combines with 'i' or 'u', it creates the guna forms 'e' and 'o'. This is adding the short 'a' to zero-grade vowels.

examples.annotation: tava + iti → taveti (a + i → e)
yad + uttara → yoduttara (a + u → o)

name: Vrddhi Formation
signature: ā + i → ai, ā + u → au
mechanism: When long 'ā' combines with 'i' or 'u', it creates the vrddhi forms 'ai' and 'au'. This is adding long 'a' to zero-grade vowels.

examples.annotation: mahaa + iti → mahaiti (ā + i → ai)
bahu + uttara → bhaava uttara (u + u → ū)

name: Vowel i → Semivowel y
mechanism: When 'i' or 'ī' appears before any vowel, it converts to the semivowel 'y'. This is a palatalization shortcut - the mouth position slides to the next sound.

examples.annotation: iti + aah → ityaah (i + ā → iyā)
tami + eva → tameva (i + e → ye)

name: Vowel u → Semivowel v
mechanism: When 'u' or 'ū' appears before any vowel, it converts to the semivowel 'v'. Like i→y, this is a labial shortcut.

examples.annotation: su + asti → svasti (u + a → va)
anu + ichhati → anvechhati (u + i → vi)

name: Visarga Chameleon Rule
signature: ḥ + voiceless → ḥ, ḥ + voiced → o, ḥ + vowel → ø
mechanism: Visarga (ḥ) is context-dependent: stays before voiceless sounds, becomes 'o' before voiced, and drops before vowels. It adapts to what follows.

examples.annotation: duHkha + kartaa → duHkham kartaa (ḥ before k stays)
ramaḥ + iti → ramo iti (ḥ before vowel becomes o)
ramaḥ + atra → ramo atra (ḥ before voiced becomes o)

name: Grassmann's Law
mechanism: A word cannot contain two aspirates in successive syllables. The first aspirate drops. Think of it as aspiration conservation - the budget is one per word.

examples.annotation: √budh + ta → buddha (aspirate drops from root, final dh remains)
√gah (to go) + ta → gata (initial gh drops before t)

name: Bartholomae's Law (The Buddha Rule)
mechanism: When a voiced aspirate appears before a voiceless consonant, the aspiration jumps forward. The Buddha Rule (√budh + ta → buddha) shows this perfectly.

examples.annotation: √budh + ta → buddha (dh aspiration jumps to t → dha)
√lagh + na → laghna (gh aspiration jumps → gha)

name: Velar Consonant Assimilation
mechanism: Final velars before voiced sounds become voiced, before voiceless stay voiceless. Nasals before velars become velar nasals.

examples.annotation: ek + pada → ekpada (k before p stays voiceless)
shat + gavaa → shaTa gavaa (t before g becomes voiced T)

name: Final Consonant + Nasal → Proper Nasal
mechanism: When any consonant appears before a nasal, it assimilates to the nasal of its own column. Velars before nasals become ŋ, palatals become ñ, etc.

examples.annotation: shak + na → shaGna (k before n becomes velar nasal ŋ)
vach + na → vaGna (ch before n becomes palatal nasal ñ)
